item.title: Bringing a Gaming PC to College?
item.dc:creator: Neil
item.category: bringing a gaming pc to school
item.description: I made a video discussing five things you should consider when choosing whether or not to bring a gaming PC to college. Most of these [...]
item.content:encoded: I made a video discussing five things you should consider when choosing whether or not to bring a gaming PC to college.  Most of these will also apply to any high performance PC.  I’m not really a gamer, but I did have a computer at home for video editing.  Hopefully this is helpful to you in making your decision.  Enjoy.

item.title: A Free Premiere Replacement? – DaVinci Resolve
item.dc:creator: Neil
item.description: I released a new video today where I discussed what factors Premiere editors should consider when deciding if they can replace Premiere with DaVinci Resolve. [...]
item.content:encoded: I released a new video today where I discussed what factors Premiere editors should consider when deciding if they can replace Premiere with DaVinci Resolve.  Over the course of editing this video, I actually found solutions to a few of my complains and ended up cutting those parts out.   After gaining more experience using this tool, perhaps I’ll make a video exploring the software in more detail.  Enjoy.

item.title: Moto X Pure Edition (2015) Review
item.dc:creator: Neil
item.description: Due to a recent failure of my LG G4, I had to quickly search for a new phone. Whether or not it’s the best phone [...]
item.content:encoded:
Due to a recent failure of my LG G4, I had to quickly search for a new phone.  Whether or not it’s the best phone for me, I’ve landed with the Moto X Pure Edition.  It’s fits what I needed better than most Android phones, but I would’ve preferred that my G4 keep working.

Here’s my YouTube video where I discuss the important aspects of the phone in more detail:

As always, I appreciate suggestions for anything you’d like to see me write or make a video about.  You can use the YouTube comments, or the comments on this page.

item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded: I know it’s been a while, but I’ve finally found time to put together another video.  This week I’ll be covering my opinion on what to look for in a phone with a long lifespan, I hope you enjoy it.

item.title: A Free Lightroom Alternative?
item.dc:creator: Neil
item.description: As I mentioned in a previous post, I’m trying to move away from subscription based software, and in particular, Adobe’s Creative Cloud. Don’t get me [...]
item.content:encoded:
As I mentioned in a previous post, I’m trying to move away from subscription based software, and in particular, Adobe’s Creative Cloud.  Don’t get me wrong, their software is fantastic, but it just isn’t affordable for someone who doesn’t use it for work everyday.  For photo processing, I was willing to spend money on a one time purchase, but instead I found a free piece of software called LightZone that might do the trick.  I thought the best way to make a comparison would be with a YouTube video, so here it is:

Hopefully you were able to watch my video, but if not, here’s a summary of my main points:

  • LightZone is also available on Linux, which Lightroom is not
  • LightZone doesn’t use a huge catalog file, which is a plus for me
  • Some tips for using LightZone:
    • Set the image size smaller to save files faster
    • Select image effects from the toolbar on the right
    • Some commands are different from Lightroom, but you can get the same effect most of the time
  • There are more errors than Lightroom, but you get what you pay for (and probably a little bit more too)
  • At the end of the day, the result is the same as Lightroom

If you’re interested in LightZone, you can find it here.
